abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Zoonoses Control Project
            for Nepal were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was Moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: Government commitment to the continuation of the
            investment made through other HPAI projects was a crucial
            factor in achieving NZCPs PDOs in spite of the very short
            implementation period (2 years according to PAD. The
            Contributing factors to this success is the dedication of
            the Project Manager and his close collaboration with the
            WBs Team and continuity of the AICP project management and
            staff; commitment of the GoN and its provision of advance
            resources to allow for project startup and planning; and the
            recruitment of capable subject matter consultants specially
            the M & E senior consultant. Centralized and strong M
            & E and Planning Unit is crucial for effective technical
            support. The centralized system at the PMU level in
            Kathmandu provided two benefits; reduction of transaction
            cost and enhancement of intersectoral collaboration; both
            being crucial for the development of a cost effective OH
            approach. The KAP survey could be a strategic M&E tool.
            Intersectoral collaboration and high level GoN commitment
            are crucial for the development and installation of the One
            Health Approach. Keeping just one agency as the primary
            implementing partner, which is responsible for streamlining,
            consolidating and submitting the budgets requests,
            procurement plans, and audit reports have mitigated many
            coordination issues and delays. The concluding workshop
            organized by Massey University in Bhutan played an
            instrumental role in bringing the key regional stakeholders
            together and raising high level awareness on OH approach.
            Similar events are necessary in order to reinforce the need
            to form and institutionalize the OH approach to address
            zoonotic diseases.
